title: Determining depression Diagnosis
text:
Depression is a serious mental health condition that affects millions of people around the world. It can be difficult to recognize the signs and symptoms, and many people struggle to get the help they need. This project is dedicated to analyzing some of the factors that might help us predict depression.









The plot above suggests that there might not be a strong connection between a person’s weight and their risk of depression. This means that having a higher or lower BMI doesn’t necessarily mean someone will experience depression.

title: About Me
text:

title: Sources
text: The Data for this project was sourced from kaggle. The dataset contains information regarding depression and anxiety among primarily college aged adults.

title: Model
text:
Estimate  Est.Error        Q2.5      Q97.5
Intercept -6.7037892 1.44177651 -9.52381228 -3.8553249
age        0.1517260 0.06727163  0.01668125  0.2798496
gender     0.3928052 0.27453893 -0.14588800  0.9466423
suicidal   0.3705045 0.40610193 -0.46674280  1.1289525
phq_score  0.1129979 0.02905443  0.05737181  0.1700719









Using the summary from the binomial Bayesian model, it is reasonable to assume that phq score, age and suicidal intentions are veritable predictors of depression levels, since they are all positively correlated with depression diagnosis.
